description:
I've started working on a TransferFunctionHelper object that helps set up and display a transfer function.  I'd like to get some feedback on this before it gets accepted. 

Here is a notebook showing how it works:
[ https://hub.yt-project.org/nb/dnryzu]( https://hub.yt-project.org/nb/dnryzu)

I think two obvious pieces would be to change the way the images are handled as well as how to handle the links between the parameter file in ParameterFileHelper and that in the camera object.

Update 1: Addressing a few simple issues. This PR will stay open for quite a while as we figure out use cases, functionality requests, and implementation details, all of which are welcome.
title: Transfer Function Helper

content.raw: Hey Sam, is this is a bugfix or something you had to do to enable the new helper routine?  Just out of curiosity.
content.html: Hey Sam, is this is a bugfix or something you had to do to enable the new helper routine? Just out of curiosity.

content.raw: This is really awesome.  I'm going to try to test this out in the next couple of days.
content.html: This is really awesome. I'm going to try to test this out in the next couple of days.

content.raw:
Hi Sam, I like this -- and the notebook is great.  One thing I wanted to bring up is something you said on Saturday, which is that I don't think this should necessarily be a separate class from TransferFunction itself.  What would be very nice, but perhaps would warrant an invasive change, would be to completely unify *all* of the transfer function classes and instead of having different classes, have different `@classmethod` constructors that build classes.  The interface you have constructed here is *considerably* nicer than the main TransferFunction interface, and this would go very, very nicely with the work @chummels , @Astrodude87 and @wgray04 have been working on in YTEP-0012: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-request/12/refactoring-for-volume-rendering-and-movie/diff .

One option would be to add this, start transitioning in 2.x, and then in 3.0 consolidate all the classes.  Would you be on board with this?
content.html:
Hi Sam, I like this -- and the notebook is great. One thing I wanted to bring up is something you said on Saturday, which is that I don't think this should necessarily be a separate class from TransferFunction itself. What would be very nice, but perhaps would warrant an invasive change, would be to completely unify all of the transfer function classes and instead of having different classes, have different @classmethod constructors that build classes. The interface you have constructed here is considerably nicer than the main TransferFunction interface, and this would go very, very nicely with the work Cameron Hummels , Mark Richardson and William Gray have been working on in YTEP-0012: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-request/12/refactoring-for-volume-rendering-and-movie/diff .

One option would be to add this, start transitioning in 2.x, and then in 3.0 consolidate all the classes. Would you be on board with this?

content.raw: bugfix. keeps map_to_colormap from erroring if you attempt to map outside the bounds of the TF.  if this doesn't get pulled in shortly i'll submit a separate bugfix commit/PR
content.html: bugfix. keeps map_to_colormap from erroring if you attempt to map outside the bounds of the TF. if this doesn't get pulled in shortly i'll submit a separate bugfix commit/PR

content.raw: I think we should put this in in a separate fix, because I want to hold off on bringing *this* change in until after 2.5.4 is out, so it can be documented.
content.html: I think we should put this in in a separate fix, because I want to hold off on bringing this change in until after 2.5.4 is out, so it can be documented.

content.raw: This should be initialized in the constructor, and set to None in the class definition.
content.html: This should be initialized in the constructor, and set to None in the class definition.

content.raw: Thanks. I like the initial capability of it, but agree that I think this needs to be baked in closer with everything else.  I think this would align much better with the camera refactor if we also refactor the TF editing at the same time. So yeah, I think we could add this after some more review/input/testing then move to a fairly invasive change in 3.0.
content.html: Thanks. I like the initial capability of it, but agree that I think this needs to be baked in closer with everything else. I think this would align much better with the camera refactor if we also refactor the TF editing at the same time. So yeah, I think we could add this after some more review/input/testing then move to a fairly invasive change in 3.0.

content.raw: +1 on it not being a separate class.
content.html: +1 on it not being a separate class.

content.raw:
Hi Sam,

I gave this a shot, and on my dataset, it throws this error:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3666/

when i follow the first 5 cells of your notebook,

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/url/hub.yt-project.org/notebooks/9bb2efeae63b49d4bfc98fbaf813aac1.ipynb

Any ideas?

thanks,

J

content.raw:
Hi Jeff, 
I can't seem to reproduce that. I've tried various ways of breaking it with weird fields and different datasets.  Somehow the x0,y0 of the bounding box that mpl is making is None. Any chance you are on a weird mpl install, or something like that?  If the data is small I'm happy to give it a shot locally if all else fails.
content.html: Hi Jeff, I can't seem to reproduce that. I've tried various ways of breaking it with weird fields and different datasets. Somehow the x0,y0 of the bounding box that mpl is making is None. Any chance you are on a weird mpl install, or something like that? If the data is small I'm happy to give it a shot locally if all else fails.

content.raw: Ok, that's weird. I'm using a stock matplotlib 1.2.1 installed by the yt install script. Maybe I can send you my dataset. It's 1.2 GB, so not tiny, but not enormous either. I was thinking I could put it on hex (if that's ok with @MatthewTurk ).
content.html: Ok, that's weird. I'm using a stock matplotlib 1.2.1 installed by the yt install script. Maybe I can send you my dataset. It's 1.2 GB, so not tiny, but not enormous either. I was thinking I could put it on hex (if that's ok with Matthew Turk ).

content.raw: It looks like there's an issue with matplotlib 1.2.1.  I'm seeing the same error as Jeff on my linux box.
content.html: It looks like there's an issue with matplotlib 1.2.1. I'm seeing the same error as Jeff on my linux box.

content.raw: Looks like it's fixed in 1.3.0RC2, so I guess this is a regression in 1.2.1.  Not sure if there's a way to get around this without waiting for 1.3.0 to come out.
content.html: Looks like it's fixed in 1.3.0RC2, so I guess this is a regression in 1.2.1. Not sure if there's a way to get around this without waiting for 1.3.0 to come out.

content.raw: That's matplotlib's [issue 1882](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/1882)
content.html: That's matplotlib's issue 1882

content.raw: Maybe we should hold off until 1.3.0 and make an upgrade part of this.
content.html: Maybe we should hold off until 1.3.0 and make an upgrade part of this.

content.raw: Yeah, though if they put out a 1.2.2 or something that'd work as well.  In the meantime, I'll work on a more fully baked in TF rewrite. Should I just decline this PR for now?
content.html: Yeah, though if they put out a 1.2.2 or something that'd work as well. In the meantime, I'll work on a more fully baked in TF rewrite. Should I just decline this PR for now?

content.raw: Have you tried the workaround mentioned in the github issue?  I think if you soecify a bottom keyword you won't be hit by the buggy default value in 1.2.1 and it will still work as expected in other versions.
content.html: Have you tried the workaround mentioned in the github issue? I think if you soecify a bottom keyword you won't be hit by the buggy default value in 1.2.1 and it will still work as expected in other versions.

content.raw: I'd rather we not decline, as long as your new work will build on these changesets.  It's okay to have an open, long-lived PR.
content.html: I'd rather we not decline, as long as your new work will build on these changesets. It's okay to have an open, long-lived PR.

content.raw: Not yet -- I'll do so in the next go at it.
content.html: Not yet -- I'll do so in the next go at it.

content.raw: Ok, sounds good.
content.html: Ok, sounds good.

content.raw:
the 'bounds' input isn't being caught here.  Just needs an:

```

else:
    self.bounds=bounds
```

I think.

content.raw: It occurred to me that one could maybe use the logic behind this to allow color transfer functions to make automatic educated guesses about where to set Gaussians and how wide to make them just by looking at the mass profile for the field to be rendered.
content.html: It occurred to me that one could maybe use the logic behind this to allow color transfer functions to make automatic educated guesses about where to set Gaussians and how wide to make them just by looking at the mass profile for the field to be rendered.

content.raw: Hi @samskillman this is really great.  I know you expressed a desire to not accept something before it's done, and instead try to focus on improving it before it goes in.  But could we accept or decline this now, and then continue to iterate?  (FWIW, I have used it and love it.)
content.html: Hi Sam Skillman this is really great. I know you expressed a desire to not accept something before it's done, and instead try to focus on improving it before it goes in. But could we accept or decline this now, and then continue to iterate? (FWIW, I have used it and love it.)

content.raw: I think this is fine to accept. For now it will act as a helper in 2.x, and we can break it in 3.0
content.html: I think this is fine to accept. For now it will act as a helper in 2.x, and we can break it in 3.0
